Awarding Retroactive Benefits Based on a Law Change
Under
38 CFR 3.114(a)
, VA may award retroactive benefits if the claimant had potential entitlement at the time the liberalizing law, VA issue, such as certain precedent opinions of VA General Counsel, or regulation became effective.
This regulation applies to
cases involving pending or previously denied claims, and
original claims filed after the change in law or administrative issue.
Note
:  A liberalizing law is one which brings about a substantive change in the law creating a new and different entitlement to a benefit.
References
:  For more information on
determining whether a law is liberalizing, see
Brown v. Nicholson
, 21 Vet.App. 290 (2007)
Spencer v. Brown
, 17 F. 3d 368, 372 (Fed. Cir. 1994), and
Green v. Brown
, 10 Vet.App. 100, 116 (1997)
the liberalizing effect of
38 CFR 3.304(f)(3)
for certain claims for SC for PTSD, see
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 1.D.2.d
, and
Ortiz v. McDonough
, 6 F. 4th 1267 (Fed Cir. 2021), and
the impact of liberalizing laws on claims for pension, see
M21-1, Part IX, Subpart iii, 1.A.2.h
, and
M21-1, Part IX, Subpart iii, 1.A.4.d
.
